direction.raw_text: Well, I'm sorry to say you have had a significant drop in the high- decibel range of your right ear.

She sits to the left of Elliot, who's at the head of the table. On his right is Evan; April sits next to him.  She and the other guests sit with their backs to the screen.  The table overflows with food, floral decorations, and candles.  In the background, the children sit at a separate table; a maid serves them turkey.  The guests chatter comfortably among themselves as they eat.

TV STUDIO CORRIDOR - NIGHT Metal elevator doors open and Mickey Sachs, a high-powered television producer, walks out, deep in conversation with his assistants, Paul and Larry.  As the elevator operator begins to reclose the door with his passengers, Mickey, his assistants fast behind, walks down an office corridor past busy groups of studio personnel.  Indistinct conversation, as well as the jazz, is heard in the background as the trio talk.

direction.raw_text: you know, I won't go to the opera.

direction.raw_text: Is this your first job?

direction.raw_text: (shaking his head) Oh no.  Not at all. As Holly carries the quiche outside to the party, April comes back into the kitchen from another doorway.  Music, as well as the chatter of mingling guests, is heard in the background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We need more bread and some baked lasa-- (realizing Holly isn't there and, at the same time, noticing David) uh, lasagne. (turning to David) Hi.

direction.raw_text: (standing by the sink as he wipes his hands and mouth with a napkin) I know.  You're an actress with a great flair for shrimp puffs.

direction.raw_text: (working at the stove, pointing a finger for emphasis) Uh, no, the shrimp puffs are Holly's.  I do the, uh, crepes caviar. She walks past David to a counter where she begins to fold napkins.  David leans back against the sink.

direction.raw_text: And the quail is responsible for the quail eggs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (turning to David and chuckling) Well, let's hope so. Holly enters the kitchen holding out a plate of clams.  She walks over to David.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here, I stole you a couple of extra clams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (taking the plate) Ah!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking busily around the room) Now.

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, gesturing) Incidentally, I'm David Tolchin.

direction.raw_text: (turning to David) Oh, uh, April Knox.  Hi. They shake hands.

direction.raw_text: (looking at her) Hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (leaving the counter and squeezing past David and Holly) Oh.

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, moving out of April's way) I'm sorry. April walks offscreen to another area of the kitchen.  Holly picks up a napkin from the crowded table.

direction.raw_text: (overlapping Holly's apology, turning to her) You're Holly.

direction.raw_text: (nodding, looking at David as she wipes her hands with the napkin) Yeah, we're the Stanislavski Catering Company.

direction.raw_text: (chewing on a clam canape) Now I'm going to tell you the truth. I really came in here because I was bored stiff by the party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (laughing, still wiping her hands) What makes you think we're more interesting? David walks around the table, putting the plate of clams down on the already crowded surface.  Holly follows him, chuckling, throwing her napkin into an offscreen garbage can as David stops at a small television set near the doorway. Guests in the other room can be seen chatting together in clusters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (turning on the set) Actually, I'm going to listen to Aida, if I'm not getting in your way. Canned laughter and miscellaneous chatter is heard from the television set.  David watches the set, still munching on a clam, while Holly and April reassure him offscreen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) No...no.  No-- (sniffing)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, overlapping) Not at all. David checks his wristwatch as Holly walks over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing, fiddling with another napkin) We saw, um, Pavarotti, eh, uh, in Ernani at the Met, and I cried...

direction.raw_text: (nodding, his hand still on his watch as he looks at Holly) I cry at the opera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Oh, I-I-I go limp in the last scene in La Traviata.  Limp. Holly chuckles as David, listening to April, impressed, walks over to her.  She is standing by the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nodding, to April) Me, too.  I have a private box at the Met. (gesturing) I bring my little bottle of wine, I open it, I sit there and I watch and (glancing over to the offscreen Holly) I cry.  It's disgusting. April chuckles as Holly walks back onscreen; she is busy preparing another tray of hors d'oeuvres.

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) Oh, what, what do you do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nodding) I'm an architect.

direction.raw_text: Wha-- (turning to glance at Holly) What kind of things do you build?

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.

direction.raw_text: (nodding) Yeah.

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Wow, it's the red one?

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Oh, it's magnificent!

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Yeah.

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) It's terrific! The film moves down from the buildings to reveal the trio sitting in David's Jaguar across the street.  David and April sit in the front seat; Holly sits scrunched up in back, her head slightly forward.

direction.raw_text: (gesturing, looking back and forth from the buildings to Holly and April) The design's deliberately noncontextural.  But I wanted to... keep the atmosphere of the street, you know, and the proportions.

direction.raw_text: (nodding) Uh-huh.

direction.raw_text: And in the material. That's...that's unpolished red granite. (pausing as he watches Holly and April's reaction)

direction.raw_text: Oh!

direction.raw_text: (nodding, overlapping) Right.

direction.raw_text: (looking back at the building with reverence) It's almost...almost, uhhh, entirely wholly interdependent, if you know what I mean.  I-I... I can't put it into words.  The important thing is-is-is it-it breathes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (turning to April, emphatically) You know, April, people pass by vital structures in this city all the time, and they never take the time to appreciate them.  I get the feeling you tune in to your environment.

direction.raw_text: (shaking her head) Oh--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting, gesturing and nodding) Oh, it's really important. David turns and briefly glances at Holly; he then turns back to April.

direction.raw_text: You want to see some?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nodding) Oh, yeah.

direction.raw_text: Well, let's do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking at David) Great. David starts the car and the movie cuts to an unfolding visual excursion through New York City's landmark buildings, as seen from the trio's point of view in the moving Jaguar. Inspiring classical music plays in the background. The series of shots includes the Dakota, complete with surrounding winter trees, the Graybar building on Lexington Avenue, an incredibly ornate building on Seventh Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, a red-stone church, an old building with embellished, bulging windows on West Forty-fourth Street, the Art Deco Chrysler Building, a red-brick building, Abigail Adams's old stone house, and the Pomander Walk nestled off Broadway on the Upper West Side.  The group can be seen walking down the path between the old-fashioned row houses and shrubbery.  A lamppost sits in the foreground. It is now dark.  The music continues to play as the film cuts to the facade of a rococo-style building, complete with French doors and ornate windows.  The admiring group is heard offscreen.

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Oh, it's just so romantic.  I just want to put on a long gown...

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, overlapping) Yes.

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Yeah.

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, overlapping) It feels like you're in France.

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) And it's got a handsome partner sitting right beside it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, overlapping) They fit right in together.  And your eye goes along, lulled into complacency, and then... The film moves from the two elegant facade to show an ugly, ultra-modern structure covered with tiny, diamond-shaped motifs.

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) That's just -- DAVID (offscreen, interrupting) Look at this.

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, continuing) ...a monstrosity!  Who would do that?

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, overlapping) It's really terrible.

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, emphatically) It's really sad.

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) And it ruins everything else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, agreeing) It does. The film moves from the ugly facade to the building's equally ugly entrance.  A large car is parked right in front of the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Well...we have seen a lot of stuff today, though.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, chuckling) Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, overlapping) Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, overlapping) A lot of works. The group is now seen walking down the canopied entrance stairs of an apartment house on the other side of the street, where they'd been gazing at both the lovely and ugly facades across the way.  David is in the lead; the women follow, Holly slightly behind April.

direction.raw_text: (nodding) Yeah.

direction.raw_text: (glancing at his watch) Maybe we should start thinking about going home, huh?

direction.raw_text: Fast.

direction.raw_text: Oh, geez, yeah.

direction.raw_text: (overlapped) Okay. They walk towards the car.

direction.raw_text: Uh -- HOLLY (overlapping, looking at April) Oh, gee, I don't know.  Um...

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, to Holly) Well, sometimes, some, uh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting) I mean, it's jammed.  If we went... um... Both she and April mumble awkwardly.

direction.raw_text: Well, I-I guess if you live in Chelsea, that's probably first.

direction.raw_text: (nodding nervously) Oh, okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.

The movie cuts briefly to cut to the traffic and lights of a Manhattan avenue as seen from the moving Jaguar.  It then moves to a close-up of Holly, sitting in the backseat, her head near the window.  She is staring straight ahead.

direction.raw_text: Naturally I get taken home first. Well, obviously he prefers April. Of course I was so tongue-tied all night.  I can't believe I said that about the Guggenheim.  My stupid little roller-skating joke.  I should never tell jokes.  Mom can tell 'em and Hannah, but I kill 'em. (glaring at the offscreen April's back) Where did April come up with that stuff about Adolph Loos and terms like "organic form"? (looking out the side window, pausing for a moment) Well, naturally.  She went to Brandeis. The movie cuts to Holly's point of view: the front seat where David and April sit, the Jaguar's windshield, and the passing lights and traffic of the street.  Holly continues her ruminations as April leans over to say something to David.

direction.raw_text: But I don't think she knows what she's talking about.  Could you believe the way she was calling him David? "Yes, David.  I feel that way, too, David.  What a marvelous space, David." (emphatically) I hate April.  She's pushy. The film moves back to Holly in the backseat, still lost in thought.

direction.raw_text: Now they'll dump me and she'll invite him up.  I blew it. (sighing, looking out the side window) And I really like him a lot.  Oh, screw it.  I'm not gonna get all upset.  I've got reading to do tonight.  You know, maybe I'll get into bed early.  I'll turn to a movie and take an extra Seconal. The classical music stops and some uptempo jazz begins.  The screen cuts to black and a title appears. "...nobody, not even the rain, has such small hands."

direction.raw_text: (trying not to sound out of breath) Oh, my goodness!

direction.raw_text: Hi.

direction.raw_text: (laughing) Ohhhh!

direction.raw_text: Oh.  Well, I live--

direction.raw_text: Oh, my goodness.  Well, why do you still go to those?  You never tough alcohol. They begin to walk down the street.

direction.raw_text: Yeah, unhappy and fat. (chuckling) And I still find the meetings very comforting, you know. She shrugs.

direction.raw_text: I'll never understand it.  You're so bright and charming and beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (laughing) Oh, God.

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, chuckling) I think to myself (laughing) what problems could she possibly have?

direction.raw_text: (gesturing, laughing) Don't let me get started on my childhood. (stopping in her tracks, remembering) Oh, you know what?  There is a bookstore.

direction.raw_text: (stopping alongside her) Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, pointing) A couple of blocks from here.  If you don't know about it, you should. You'd really love it.

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nodding) Yeah, you would.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking around for a moment, then gesturing to Lee) Well, i-if-if you have some free time...

direction.raw_text: (nodding) Yeah, sure. (chuckling)

direction.raw_text: Thank you. They begin to walk again as the movie cuts to the interior of the Pageant Book & Print Shop, an old, serious bookstore. A nude print hangs at the end of one of the library shelf- like bookcases, which are packed, row after row, with books. An unseen Elliot and Lee carry on a conversation as the camera moves down an aisle, past the rows of books.  A piano playing "Bewitched" is heard.  Pictures hang on the aisle ends of the shelves.

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT. STREET CORNER - DAY Mickey stands in a telephone booth on a corner near Dr. Abel's office; he talks on the phone.  It is raining.  A man and a woman holding an umbrella pass by; traffic moves across a nearby intersection.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. MICKEY'S OFFICE - NIGHT Gail, wearing her glasses, stands behind a crowded but well- ordered desk.  Two assistants, a man and a woman, stand around her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT. MANHATTAN STREET - DAY A contemporary red building, designed by David, is seen, squeezed in between two older buildings.  Holly, April, and David talk offscreen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT. STREET OUTSIDE FREDERICK'S LOFT - DAY The movie briefly holds on a ripped, red, paint-splattered door as Elliot, wearing a raincoat, appears nearby.  He looks down the street and the film cuts to his point of view: Frederick's loft building. The movie goes back to the impatient Elliot; he's looking around him.  He glances at his watch as the film cuts back once again to the loft building, where Lee finally appears, walking down the street away from Elliot.  A truck passes down the street.  Lee doesn't see him.  She walks further and further away; she turns a corner. Elliot frantically looks around again; then, in a burst of decision, he runs around a garbage dump, crossing the street, and still running, he moves down an adjacent street, past The Canal Lumber Company and several other buildings, as the film cuts back to Lee, walking down a different street, oblivious. The jazz plays on as the movie cuts back and forth between the fast-moving Elliot, rushing down the SoHo streets, past a truck waiting for a light to change, past some pedestrians, some garbage cans, turning corners, and the strolling Lee, walking up different streets, past different buildings. Lee eventually crosses a street, lost in thought, looking right and left, as Elliot, pretending nonchalance, waits on the corner, looking at his watch.  She looks up in surprise; the music stops.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: read a poem of you and thought of his last week. (nervously laughing, trying to correct his mistake) A poem of (laughing) his and thought of you last-- (laughing) You'll be fine, though. (chuckling) Lee walks over to Elliot in the center aisle.  She looks at the book.

direction.raw_text: (overlapping) Uh, uh, this is great.  I mean, I love e.e. cummings, but I can't let you get this.

direction.raw_text: (looking down at the book) Well, sure.

direction.raw_text: Bye.

direction.raw_text: (reading) "your slightest look easily will unclose me though I have closed myself as fingers, you open always petal by petal myself... As Lee continues to read aloud, the movie cuts to Elliot's darkened den, lit by a light in the hallway.  Elliot enters, wearing a robe, crossing the room in the dark.

direction.raw_text: (continuing reading)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. FREDERICK'S LOFT BEDROOM - NIGHT Lee, in slacks and shirt, is curled up on the bed, her back to the camera, as she reads the e.e. cummings poem in the glow of a night-table lamp.  The piano music is still heard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...as Spring opens [touching skillfully, mysteriously] her first rose [i do not know what it is about you that closes and opens; only something in me understands the voice of your eyes is deeper than all roses]... Elliot turns on a light.  The camera stays on his face as he looks off into the distance, mouthing indistinctly the line of poetry Lee next reads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (continuing reading) "nobody, not even the rain, has such small hands." The film leaves Elliot's face and cuts back to the loft, where Lee, having finished the poem, sits up in the bed, staring pensively, lost in her thoughts.

direction.raw_text: (putting down the book) We'll go. The film moves outside the loft building.  Dusty and Elliot emerge and walk to Dusty's waiting limousine.  Elliot is rubbing his forehead, anguished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (angrily, getting into the car) What a weirdo that guy is!  Paranoid. (noticing Elliot's anguished face) What's the matter with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) Look I-I-I'll be okay.  I'll be okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping) It's not that big a deal.  We just didn't hit it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) Now, look, you-you-you go on ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you okay?  You look-- You're sweatin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, nervously) Yeah.  Yeah, I just-just need so- some-some fresh air.  It's probably something I ate.  I'll-I'll walk. You go ahead. Dusty settles down in the backseat and closes the door. Elliot leans down to the chauffeur's window, signaling for him to start driving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (continuing, gesturing) You go.  Go on.  Go. The limousine drives off.  Elliot runs to a phone booth across the street.  He picks up the phone and dials. The film cuts to Frederick in his loft, standing near the phone.  It rings.  Frederick picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into the telephone) Hello?  Hello?  Hello? When no one answers, Frederick, reacting, hangs up, and the film moves back outside to the phone booth, where Elliot, the phone receiver to his ear, listens for a moment, then hangs up.  He walks out of the booth, reacting, then walks down the sidewalk, where he bumps into a frantic Lee, just turning the corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing in relief) Oh!  There you are! Elliot mumbles, relieved and confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was looking for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must apologize.  I-I'm, I-I'm sorry.  I'm so mixed up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) Well, how do you expect me to react to such a thing? Elliot, uneasy, glances up in the direction of Frederick's loft.  He leads Lee a few yards up the street, away from any prying eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (taking Lee's arm) Wh--, uh, I know, I know but, I am in love with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, don't say those words!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, shaking his head)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.  I know it's terrible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pushing back her hair, shaking her head hopelessly) Why, you know the situation. She sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking away for a moment) I know!  I-I-I-I, I realize.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you expect me to say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hannah and I are in the last stages.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shaking her head) Wh-- She's never said anything, and we're very close.  She'd tell me such a thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wh--, it-it-it-it, it's so sad. She's crazy about me, but somewhere on the, along the line, I've fallen out of love with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not because of me, I hope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, no, no. (nodding) Well, yes!  I love you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I can't be the cause of anything between you and Hannah.  I jus--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, shaking his head) Oh, no, no, no.  It, uh, it-it-it- it was i-inevitable that Hannah and I part, anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tch, w-well, for a million reasons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) But not over me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tch, no!  We were, we were both going in different directions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking down) Poor Hannah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But-but, but how about you?  Do you, do you share any of my feelings? Or is this just an unpleasant embarrassment to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (reacting uneasily) I can't say anything!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: W-well, please be candid.  I, I-I don't want you to feel bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (putting her hand to her head) Yes!  But I...I have certain feelings for you, but don't make me say anything more, all right? Lee looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) O-o-o-okay, Lee.  Okay, okay.  You, you, y-you've said enough.  It's my responsibility now.  I will work things out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, don't do anything on my behalf. (shaking her head) I live with Frederick, and Hannah and I are close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, but you, you do care about me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (reacting) Oh, Elliot, please!  I can't be a party to this!  I'm suddenly wracked with guilt just standing her talking to you on the street! She sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (emphatically) Your guilt is because you feel the same.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (reacting) Oh, please, I have to go.  I have to get my teeth cleaned. She walks off.  Elliot stares after her, grinning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (happily) I have my answer.  I have my answer! I'm walking on air! He laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (distracted) Hi.  How's she doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping) I am glad to see you. Hannah takes off her shoulder bag and her coat as her aggravated father walks past her towards the kitchen.  He passes a wall with an ornate mirror and some framed photographs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's in the kitchen there.  It's the same thing.  Same thing.  She promises, promises. (gesturing) But it's all lies. Through a doorway, Norma can be seen sitting on a chair in the kitchen.  She wears a robe over a slip and stockings; she's drinking.  Evan stands in the doorway looking at her; he doesn't go in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, patiently) Don't make it worse, Dad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping) Always. Hannah hurriedly passes her father and enters the kitchen; her mother takes a sip of her drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Mom.  How you doing?  Here, let me get you some coffee.  That's enough of that. (taking away her mother's drink, to Evan) What triggered it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing, as Norma turns her head and watches him) We were making a commercial down at the mayor's office, and there was this young, good-looking salesman... Norma reacts, turning to her daughter.  Hannah, however, has her back turned.  She is busy taking charge in the kitchen as Evan speaks.  She takes some pills out of a cupboard and hands them to her mother with a glass of water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (continuing) ...and your mother was throwing herself at him in a disgusting way, and when she found she was too old to seduce him, that he was just embarrassed by her--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (angrily interrupting, turning her head) Liar!  Liar! The camera moves to Evan, who continues to tell his story, ignoring his wife's outburst, as he walks away from the kitchen doorway into the den.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then at lunch she got drunker and drunker (shouting over his shoulder) and finally she became Joan Collins! Evan walks over to the piano, where several framed family photographs sit in a line on its top.  He picks one up as Norma speaks offscreen in the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) All my life I've had to put up with insults... The camera moves back to the kitchen as Norma talks.  She is still glaring offscreen at the doorway where Evan stood moments before.  She holds the water glass and the pills.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (continuing, dramatically) ...from this non-person, this, th- th-this haircut that passes for a man. (turning to look at the offscreen Hannah) He could never support us.  It's a good thing we had a talented daughter! Evan is back in the doorway, listening to Norma, getting more and more angry.  As he makes a retort, he starts to walk back to the den and his piano.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can only hope that she was mine. With you as her mother (gesturing, his voice getting louder) her father could be anybody in Actors' Equity!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's talented...so it's not likely she's yours! (taking a sip of water)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (walking over to the doorway to speak to Evan, who's already fuming in the den) Dad, could you just please stay in the other room and let me take care of her? Hannah goes back to Norma; she takes the glass of water away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, choosing to ignore Hannah's suggestion) You never know when she's going to fall off the wagon and humiliate everybody. Hannah, choosing to ignore Evan's remark, hands her mother a cup of coffee; she puts her mother's hands on the cup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here, Mom.  Drink this. (leaning against a kitchen counter) You know, you're awful.  You probably were flirting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sipping her coffee) No!  I like to joke around and have fun, and he gets angry because I get the attention.  He's gotten sourer as he's gotten older, and I've tried to stay young...at heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You promised to stay on the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shaking her head) The sacrifices I've made because of that man. (inhaling) He's ruined me with his ego, his philandering, his-- (gesturing) his-his-his-his mediocrity!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, stop being so dramatic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shouting to the offscreen Evan) He's the one that's made every ingenue in stock!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (quietly) Okay, okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (touching Hannah's arm, gasping) Th-th-they, they wanted me for a screen test.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (patiently) Yeah, I know, Mom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) But I, I knew that he'd get up there and he'd flounder around with his expensive haircuts and hairdos and clothes.  He's all show! (touching Hannah's arm again, then touching her chest) Now how can you act when there's nothing inside to come out?! Norma sips her coffee, softly sobbing.  Hannah, reacting, walks away from the counter and, capping the bottle of pills, puts them back in the cupboard.  Evan plays the piano offscreen.  The camera moves in on Hannah's face as she reflects, her voice heard over the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was so beautiful at one time, and he was so dashing.  Both of them just full of promise and hopes that never materialized. The camera leaves Hannah's face as she continues to reflect; it moves to the den, to the row of family photos on the piano: one of a present-day Evan and Norma, others where both Norma and Evan are young, beautiful, hopeful.  The music plays on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the fights and the constant infidelities to prove themselves...and blaming each other. It's s-sad.  They loved the idea of having us kids, but raising us didn't interest them much.  But it's impossible to hold it against them.  They didn't know anything else. The film cuts back to the kitchen.  Norma stands up; Hannah takes her coffee cup and sets it on the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, of all of us in the family, you were the one blessed with the true gift. She puts her arm around Hannah's shoulder.  Mother and daughter walk out of the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (holding the hand her mother had placed on her shoulder) Ohhh, my true gift is luck, Mom. Norma chuckles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping) I just had a lot of luck...from my first show, you know?  I've always thought Lee was the one destined for great things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, she's lovely, but she doesn't have your spark. (gesturing and chuckling) She knows it.  She worships you. She wouldn't dare get up there on the stage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking at her mother) Now, Holly's not shy. They stop at the entrance to the den.  Evan can be seen playing the piano as they continue their conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Holly's game for anything. Holly takes after me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: True.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shaking her head) I'd have been a great dope addict. Norma chortles.  Hannah laughs, touching her mother.  They walk over to Evan at the piano.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking up) Remember this, Hannah? Evan plays a few bars of "You Are Too Beautiful" as mother and daughter, their backs to the camera, listen.  Norma leans over the piano; Hannah looks off into the distance, deep in reflection.  The piano music continues in the background as the movie cuts to: Lee walking along a wharf by the waterfront.  The wind blows her hair; she hugs the e.e. cummings book to her chest. She, too, is deep in thought.  She stops at the edge of the wharf; the camera continues to move, to a group of wooden pilings nearby, lapped by the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Sachs, (sighing) I'm afraid the news is not good. Dr. Brooks turns to an offscreen Mickey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (continuing, taking a pencil out of his pocket) If I can show you exactly where the tumor is, and why we feel that surgery would be of no use. The film quickly cuts to a close-up of Mickey's face, reacting in total despair.  He closes his eyes; he covers his face with his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's over.  I'm face-to-face with eternity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) ...grown quite large without being detected... (trailing off indistinctly as Mickey continues his anguished ramblings)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not later, but now.  I'm so frightened I can't move, speak, or breathe. As Mickey finishes his speech, the "real" Dr. Brooks is seen walking into the office.  The previous scene had been a figment of Mickey's imagination, a nightmare fantasy only. Holding Mickey's X-rays, the "real" Dr. Brooks walks past the same row of books to the light panel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you're just fine.  There's absolutely nothing here at all. And your tests are all fine. (switching on the light on the panel and propping up the X-rays) I must admit, I was concerned, given your symptoms. (turning to look at the offscreen Mickey) What caused this hearing loss in one ear, I guess we'll never really know for sure.  But whatever it was, it's certainly not anything serious at all. (nodding) I'm very relieved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean you're quitting? Why?  The news is good!  You don't have canc--the thing. Mickey, standing behind his desk, his back to the camera, his coat still on, looks out at the Manhattan skyline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you realize what a thread we're all hanging by?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Mickey, you're off the hook.  You should be celebrating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (walking around to the front of his desk, gesturing) Can you understand how meaningless everything is?  Everything!  I'm talking about nnnn--our lives, the show...the whole world, it's meaningless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) Yeah...but you're not dying!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm not dying now, but, but (gesturing) you know, when I ran out of the hospital, I, I was so thrilled because they told me I was going to be all right.  And I'm running down the street, and suddenly I stop, 'cause it hit me, all right, so, you know, I'm not going to go today. I'm okay.  I'm not going to go tomorrow. (pointing) But eventually, I'm going to be in that position. Gail gets up from her chair.  She walks past Mickey to a nearby cabinet.  She opens a drawer, rummaging around for something.  The camera follows her, leaving Mickey briefly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're just realizing this now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Well, I don't realize it now, I know it all the time, but, but I managed to stick it in the back of my mind... As Mickey continues to talk offscreen, Gail closes the cabinet drawer and walks to a file cabinet behind Mickey's desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...because it-it's a very horrible thing to... think about! Gail opens the file cabinet and takes out a pack of gum. She slams it closed, distracted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (muttering) Yeah.  What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (turning to Gail) Can I tell you something?  Can I tell you a secret?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nodding impatiently as she walks around the desk) Yes, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pointing) A week ago, I bought a rifle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sitting on the arm of a chair near Mickey) No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, nodding and gesturing) I went into a store, I bought a rifle.  I was gonna... You know, if they told me that I had a tumor, I was going to kill myself.  The only thing that mighta stopped me, might've, is my parents would be devastated.  I would, I woulda had to shoot them, also, first.  And then, I have an aunt and uncle, I would have... You know, it would have been a bloodbath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shrugging, unwrapping a stick of gum) Tch, well, you know, eventually it, it is going to happen to all of us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, but doesn't that ruin everything for you?  That makes everything... Gail sighs.  She pops a piece of gum into her mouth as Mickey continues to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (continuing) ...you know it, it just takes the pleasure out of everything. (gesturing, pointing) I mean, you're gonna die, I'm gonna die, the audience is gonna die, the network's gonna-- The sponsor. Everything!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (chewing) I know, I know, and your hamster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nodding emphatically) Yes!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (chewing and pointing to Mickey) Listen, kid, I think you snapped your cap. Mickey sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (continuing, chewing loudly) Maybe you need a few weeks in Bermuda, or something.  Or go to a whorehouse!  No?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shaking his head, his hand to his chest) I can't stay on this show.  I gotta get some answers.  Otherwise (pausing and holding his head) I'm telling you, I'm going to do something drastic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking intensely at Lee, his hands in his pockets) I thought you weren't coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I almost didn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (putting his hand on her shoulder, wanting to kiss her) Lee... uh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't sleep all night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (taking his hand away, gesturing to the room) No, no-no-no, I'm sure. They walk towards the camera, further into the room.  Elliot puts his arm around Lee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are we doing, meeting in a hotel room?  It's terrible, isn't it? The music stops.  The camera follows Lee as she walks towards the curtained windows, past a fireplace, a mirror, some innocuous pictures, a delicate table holding a lamp, the foot of the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen)
direction.name: direction

result.heading: STREET CORNER OUTSIDE EVAN AND NORMA'S APARTMENT BUILDING

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT. STREET CORNER OUTSIDE EVAN AND NORMA'S APARTMENT BUILDING - DAY A taxi turns a West Side street corner and stops in front of Evan and Norma's building, which is decorated with a long metal awning.  It's an overcast day. A station wagon on the opposite side of the street pulls away as Hannah, a white scarf fluttering over her shoulder, gets out of the cab.  She runs into the building; the taxi drives away.  A piano plays "Bewitched" over the screen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. EVAN AND NORMA'S APARTMENT - DAY Evan, his back to the camera, walks to the front door and opens it to Hannah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : The abyss. The piano piece ends and the film is quiet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. HOSPITAL CAT-SCAN ROOM - DAY The quiet continues as the film cuts to a close-up of a large, circular CAT-scan module in an antiseptic hospital room.  A slowly moving stretcher, bearing Mickey's strapped prone body, begins to enter the round opening of the module. As the camera pulls back from Mickey, his taped head under the scan, two technicians can be seen through the window separating the scanner from the control room.  One of them, sitting down, taps information into a computer while the other technician stands nearby, looking from Mickey to the computer screen. The movie then cuts briefly to the computer screen, showing an image of Mickey's skull.  Scan lines bleep over the skull. The camera moves up from the screen to reveal Mickey once again, as seen through the window, silent and serious under the CAT-scan module. From Mickey's prone form, the film moves to the two technicians, as seen through the window in the scanner room. They examine the computer screen and talk indistinctly to each other.  One of the men, nodding, taps more information into the computer. While they're studying the CAT-scan picture, the camera cuts to a back view of Mickey under the module.  There is a science-fiction feel to this scene, as if Mickey is lying in the center of a huge, white, futuristic circle.  The stretcher, bearing Mickey, slowly moves out of the module.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. DR. BROOK'S OFFICE - DAY Dr. Brooks, holding Mickey's X-rays, walks past a row of bookshelves to his light panel.  He props up the X-rays.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT. MOUNT SINAI HOSPITAL - DAY Once again, Mickey is seen leaving the building, but this time he bounds down the steps, jumping for joy.  He runs swirling down the street, clapping his hands, happy with relief.  Upbeat, uptempo jazz plays in the background. Several cars pass as Mickey joyfully runs.  Suddenly he stops, his hand to his mouth, reflecting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. MICKEY'S OFFICE - DAY Gail sits in a chair in front of a bookshelf.  A sofa, a coffee table holding periodicals, and an endtable with a lamp complete the tableau.  Gail's hands are clasped on her lap.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : The entrance to the St. Regis Hotel, elegant and warmly lit in the night.  Pedestrians pass.  Baroque harpsichord music plays over the scene.  The camera moves up the hotel's facade, past its welcoming flags, to its ornate windows several floors up. As the harpsichord continues to play, the film moves inside, to one of the hotel rooms.  Elliot, his back to the camera, is opening the door to Lee. Elliot closes the door behind her as she enters.  They stand very close to each other, framed by the door and a stark, subtly striped wallpapered wall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: couldn't think where to invite you without taking risks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I promised myself I wouldn't let this happen till you were living alone.  I was so torn when you called. She parts a corner of the curtains, looking out the window, turning when Elliot speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) I've wanted to call you everyday since I first told you how I felt. He walks over to Lee by the curtained windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I resisted so many times. (pausing) Don't think badly of me. He takes Lee into his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is not an easy situation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering) I know it isn't. They kiss, their figures almost silhouetted in the warm glow of the room.  Elliot takes Lee's coat off without breaking the kiss.  They embrace.  They kiss each other lightly, then stronger, more passionately, their embrace much tighter. And it's later that night.  The harpsichord music begins to play again as the camera moves over the bed covers to reveal Lee, lying contentedly under the sheets, her hair fanned out on the pillows, one arm near her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was just perfect.  You've ruined me for anyone else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) I don't want anyone else ever to have you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sighing) I was so worried I wouldn't compare with Hannah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, laughing) Oh, my God. He enters the screen, sitting down on the edge of the bed next to Lee.  He holds a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really do have those thoughts, don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (chuckling, touching Elliot's arm) Oh, all the time. Elliot chuckles; they hold hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know she must be a really passionate person.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking at their clasped hands) Yes, she's, she's very warm, but, but it-it's me that wants to be giving to you.  I-I-I want to do things for you.  Hannah doesn't need me as much. (chuckling as Lee laughs) I'm being presumptuous.  Not that you need me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nodding) I want you to take care of me... And I love when you do things to me. Elliot leans down to Lee; they begin to kiss passionately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) You're late. Lee walks through the loft's living room area, unbelting her coat, towards the bathroom.  She passes Frederick, who sits at a table in the kitchen area, drinking a cup of coffee and reading the paper.  A plate with a half-eaten sandwich sits in front of him.  The music stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (opening the bathroom door) Lucy and I kept talking, and I didn't realize how late it had gotten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (barely glancing up from his paper) You missed a very dull TV show about Auschwitz.  More gruesome film clips...and more puzzled intellectuals declaring their mystification over the systematic murder of millions. As he talks, Lee is seen turning on the bathroom light.  She takes off her coat, hanging it on a hook, then begins to dry her hair with a towel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (turning his head slightly in Lee's direction and gesturing) The reason why they could never answer the question "How could it possibly happen?" is that it's the wrong question.  Given what people are, the question is (swallowing) "Why doesn't it happen more often?" Of course it does, in subtler forms. Frederick takes a bite of his sandwich and another sip of coffee as Lee walks out of the bathroom, tossing the towel down on the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (moving her fingers through her wet hair) I have a little headache from this weather. She takes a kettle and fills it with water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: know, but there's got to be some give and take. Hannah sighs.  Elliot angrily throws his napkin on the table. He stands up and begins to pace behind Hannah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, let's not--I, I don't know what the hell I'm talking about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (reacting) Are you angry with me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you feel, um...are you disenchanted with our marriage?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pointing at Hannah) I didn't say that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you in love with someone else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (angrily) My God!  Wha-what is this?  The Gestapo?  No. He sits down again, in a chair next to Hannah; the ketchup bottle sits in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (turning to look at him) Well, what?  What, wh-what are you not telling me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing and pointing) What kind of interrogation... Su- supposing I said yes?  I-I-I am disenchanted.  I am in love with someone else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (staring at Hannah for a beat before answering her) No! (gesturing) But you keep asking these, these awful questions.  My God, it's-it's like you want me to say yes!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) What, you, of c-- What are you talking about?  Of course not.  I'd be destroyed! The camera moves in on Elliot's anguished face.  He talks over the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For Chrissakes, stop torturing her. Tell her you want out and get it over with.  You're in love with her sister.  You didn't do it on purpose.  Be honest.  It's always the best way. He looks down.  Hannah leans over and tenderly puts her hand on his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (softly) Look, can I help you?  If you're suffering over something, will you share it with me? She touches his hand; Elliot embraces her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hannah, you know how much I love you. (kissing her on the forehead) I ought to have my head examined. I don't deserve you. Elliot kisses Hannah again; they embrace tightly.  She touches his hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) You know, I just want to look so good, but I don't want to seem, you know, like I'm overdressed. (onscreen, walking up the stairs behind Hannah) You know what I'm saying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, turning to look at Holly) Oh, no, not at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (holding up a dress she's carrying on her arm) Well, how about this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking at the dress) Well, I, I really like that.  I think that's a pretty color on you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping) Oh, yeah. (laughing) Hannah and Holly reach the top of the stairs.  They walk onto a cavernous, high-tech floor.  Empty bleachers line one wall; the rest of the floor is filled with racks of clothes and empty space.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (continuing, smiling) Did you ever think you'd be helping me buy something to wear to the opera? (chuckling)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (playfully hitting Holly's arm) Nuh-uh...but I think it's great.  I can't wait to meet him. Holly follows Hannah to a rack of blouses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's married...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting, looking through the rack) Oh-oh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping) ...and his wife's, uh, in and out of institutions.  She's schizophrenic. Holly continues to talk as she follows Hannah across the floor to a rack of dresses.  Hannah's on one side, flipping through the hangers.  Holly, on the other side of the same rack, talks to her sister, not looking at the clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sometimes she's terrific...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping) Oooo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and then she just breaks down. (gesturing) And he has this sweet daughter...and when she goes to college next year, he's going to split permanently.  I mean...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, looking up at Holly) Oh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...he's really paid his dues, but...then she helped put him through architecture school, you know, so... Hannah takes a jacket on a hanger off the rack and looks at it.  She holds it to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting, glancing at her sister for a moment with amazement) You found all this, all this out on one date?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (chuckling and nodding) Well, I think he was dying to open up.  It's so sad. (finally looking back and forth along the rack) Now...what should I wear to my audition? Hannah turns to Holly with surprise.  She puts the jacket back on the rack and stares at her; she inhales.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (explaining) I've got a singing audition for a Broadway musical. (chuckling) Of course, I'll never get it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Singing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (chuckling) Yeah, can you believe it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (walking around the rack to Holly, still surprised) Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (vulnerably) Well, I mean, why not?  You know, wh-what have I got to lose?  Uh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, shaking her head) Well, no...I-I know, I just, uh... No, I-I, eh, you know, I, I didn't, I didn't know you sung. Hannah begins to look at the rack of clothes on Holly's side, while her sister stares at her, frowning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (defensively) Well, you think everybody in m- musicals sings so well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing, shaking her head) No!  No, I, eh, it's just that they sing. Holly is silent for a moment.  Hannah takes a blouse off the rack and looks at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well...you know, uh...I sing a little, I mean... (chuckling self-consciously)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (realizing she's hurt Holly, reacting) Ohh!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, shaking her head) You know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (hanging the blouse back on the rack) I know, no-- (chuckling) I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, still chuckling self- consciously, gesturing) I mean, y-you know, don't say it that way, you know, because my confidence is not my strong point,
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. THE CARLYLE CLUB - NIGHT Bobby Short is playing "I'm In Love Again" on the piano, accompanied by a bass player.  An Art Deco mural fills the wall behind him...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. HANNAH'S DINING ROOM - NIGHT Elliot, Hannah, and the twins sit at the dining room table. A Christmas tree stands in the corner of the room, next to a table holding a lamp; a picture hangs on the wall.  The family has just finished eating; the table is cluttered with the remains of dinner, including a quart of milk, some chocolate syrup, and a bottle of ketchup.  Hannah's two adopted children stand by her chair; she is showing them how a small camera works.  The children watch her, fascinated, muttering among themselves.  Elliot looks listless.  He stares blankly at the table.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : The audition. There is no music.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. SOHO CLOTHING BOUTIQUE - DAY The screen shows a metal staircase next to a large white column.  Holly's voice can be heard as she and Hannah make their way up the stairs, moving into view.  A man carrying a shopping bag walks down the steps; he passes them.  Hannah and Holly talk as they climb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (interrupting, touching her sister's shoulder) No, I'm sorry.  No, I didn't mean that.  No, I didn't mean that. The two sisters walk away from the rack, Hannah slightly in the lead.  Behind them are some more racks of clothing and a large window with closed venetian blinds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) Uh, you know, I think I can fake my way through a song.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nodding as she looks around the store, pulling up her shoulder bag strap) Uh-huh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Easily. Holly pauses, looking at her sister.  They continue to walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking at Hannah) W-why?  You don't think it's realistic?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (putting her hand on Holly's shoulder) No, I didn't, I, that's no.  No, I- I-I, no, I-I just... (gesturing) hate to see you put yourself in a position where, where you get hurt, you know.  You know, you know how you take...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, nodding) Yeah. They walk over to a table laid out with colorful scarves and decorated with hurricane lamps bordering its edges.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (continuing, looking at some clothes hanging beneath the table) ...every, eh, single rejection as- as-as a...a confirmation that you have no talent, or something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, nodding) Yeah.  Well, maybe I'll get it. (chuckling and gesturing)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, looking at the clothes) I hope. Holly looks at her sister for a beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sighing) Boy, you really know how to cut me down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking at Holly, reacting) What?  You don't, don't be so sensitive.  Can't I say anything?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) Tch, well, I sing! (suddenly shouting) For Chrissake, Hannah, you heard me sing! A female customer, who'd come over to the table, browsing through the rack of clothes near Hannah, looks up, reacting. She walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, reacting to her sister's outburst) Okay! (looking at her sister) Okay.  I-- What happened?  You know, we were having a really nice time, a-and suddenly, everything went to bad feeling. She walks past Holly and briefly looks at a different rack of clothes beneath the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shaking her head) Nobody but you can do that to me. I don't know why.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) Look, everything's going your way. She walks offscreen to a nearby rack; the camera remains focused on Holly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. (pausing) I'm happy. (shrugging, looking at the offscreen Hannah) Why must I let my insecurities spoil everything? Holly chuckles and begins to look through the scarves on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, singing softly) "This year's fancies Are passing fancies..." The film moves from the audience to the stage where Holly, her hands clasped in front of her, continues to sing her song.  A large group of other hopefuls are seen in the background behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (continuing her singing, barely moving her body) "But sighing sighs Holding hands This my heart Understands I'm old-fashioned And I don't mind it It's how I want to be As long as you agree To stay old-fashioned with me." The camera moves from Holly back to the executives in the audience.  As it passes the empty audience seats, they are heard offscreen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) It was very nice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, overlapping) Terrific. The camera has reached the executives in the audience.  They are now chattering among themselves, Holly forgotten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, overlapping the executives' chatter) April Knox? The film cuts back to the stage, where April, handling the audition pianist some sheet music, prepares herself to sing "The Way You Look Tonight." The stage is very black, stark, except for April and the pianist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (singing) "Someday When I'm awfully low When the world is cold I will get a glow Just thinking of you And the way you look Tonight..."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm telling you, you sounded great. You, uh, you may be surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sighing) Oh, I'm just glad we have a catering job this week.  I'm real low on money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, we have Mr. Morris Levine's eightieth birthday party on Riverside Drive...or Riverside Memorial Chapel, depending on his health.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, uh, listen, David called me up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (reacting) What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) Uh, David called me last night, and he wants to take me to the opera. (chuckling) I didn't know what to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (reacting) You're joking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, he called late last night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sadly)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. THEATER - DAY A group of theater executives, including the producer, the director, and two assistants, sit in a cluster in the empty audience, talking; they look up at the offscreen Holly, who is auditioning on the stage.  She is singing "I'm Old- Fashioned," accompanied by a piano.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT. A STREET OUTSIDE THE THEATER - DAY A theater marquee can be seen on the busy street as Holly and April walk down the street towards the camera, moving closer and closer as they talk.  Workmen and various street noises can be heard indistinctly in the background.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: uh, I'm very surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (chuckling, gesturing) He wants to take me to see Rigoletto.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking briefly at April) And you, you-you're going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I-I-I didn't know what to say. First I said no, but then, he pressed it.  He said, uh, he'd taken you once and he really wanted to invite me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pausing) But I'm seeing him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) I know.  I said that, but... (shrugging) he said it was something he really felt like doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stopping and facing April) Gee, um... (looking off, sniffing) I...I don't know what to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, it's just an evening at the opera.  Did I, I-I do wrong in accepting? Holly looks away sadly; she shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (continuing) Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) Now why do you think that you would like to convert to Catholicism? The camera moves back to reveal Mickey, his back to the camera, sitting in front of Father Flynn's desk.  A lamp is lit in the background; the Father's desk is neat.  The room is comfortably decorated in wood and leather.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, uh, because, y-you know, I gotta have something to believe in, otherwise life is just meaningless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pacing behind his desk and gesturing) I understand.  But why did you make the decision to choose the Catholic faith? The movie cuts to Mickey's face.  He's very neat in a tie, sweater, and sports jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) Tch.  Well, y-you know...first of all, because it's a very beautiful religion.  It's very well structured. Now I'm talking now, incidentally, about the-the, uh, against-school- prayer, pro-abortion, anti-nuclear wing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) So at the moment you don't believe in God. The camera cuts back to Father Flynn, who walks over to a leather armchair next to a table set for tea.  He begins to pour the tea into china cups.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) No.  A-a-and I-I want to.  You know, I'm-I'm willing to do anything. I'll, you know, I'll dye Easter eggs if it works. (walking over to Father Flynn and sitting down in an adjacent chair)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : The big leap. The film cuts to Father Flynn's rectory office.  The Catholic priest looks out a simple stained-glass window, then turns to an offscreen Mickey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: need some evidence.  I gotta have some proof.  Uh, you know, i- i-if I can't believe in God (gesturing, his raincoat in his lap) then I don't think life is worth living.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stopping his tea pouring) It means making a very big leap. Father Flynn clasps his hands in his lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nodding, fiddling with his raincoat) Yes, well, can-can you help me? The film abruptly cuts to the long hallway in Mickey's parents' apartment. In the foreground, a section of the living room can be seen, with a bureau holding a lamp and a framed photo.  The hallway itself is crowded with pictures and a wall shelf. At the other end of the hallway, in the background, is another bureau, with candlesticks on top and a framed picture on the wall above.  Mickey's mother stands in the front of this bureau at the hallway's end, screaming at the top of her lungs, holding her heart dramatically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (crying) Why?  Oh, my God! She sobs hysterically, staggering offscreen to the bathroom; she shuts the door.  Mickey walks into view, in the living room, looking after his shocked mother, who continues to cry over the scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping and gesturing) I don't understand. (turning to his offscreen father) I thought that you would be happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) How can we be happy? His father walks into view, carrying a teacup and a candy dish.  He strides past Mickey towards the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (following his father) Well, because I never thought of God in my life.  Now I'm giving it serious thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, in the kitchen) But Catholicism?  Why not your own people?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing at the kitchen door to his offscreen father) Because I got off to a wrong foot with my own thing, you know.  B-b- b-but I need a dramatic change in my life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) You're gonna believe in Jesus Christ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) I know it sounds funny, but I'm gonna try.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) But why?  We raised you as a Jew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shrugging) So, just 'cause I was born that way... You know, I'm old enough to make a mature decision. Mickey's father walks into view; he stands by the stove near the kitchen doorway, picking up a dirty glass and some bowls to clean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But why Jesus Christ?  Why, for instance, shouldn't you become a Buddhist? Holding the dirty dishes in his hand, Mickey's father looks at his son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) A Bud--?  That's totally alien to me.  Look, you're getting on in years, right?  Aren't you afraid of dying? Mickey's father walks offscreen again, to the kitchen sink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Why should I be afraid?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (loudly gesturing) Oh! 'Cause you won't exist!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) So?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) That thought doesn't terrify you? Mickey's father walks out of the kitchen, past his son, to the living room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (waving his arm) Who thinks about such nonsense? Now I'm alive.  When I'm dead, I'll be dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (following his father, gesturing) I don't understand.  Aren't you frightened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Of what?  I'll be unconscious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (turning and walking down the hallway) Yeah, I know.  But never to exist again!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) How do you know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it certainly doesn't look promising. Mickey stops at the bathroom door at the other end of the hallway.  He starts to pound it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Who knows what'll be? Mickey's father comes back on screen; he's carrying a plate of hors d'oeuvres and an empty glass towards the kitchen. He stops and looks down the hall at Mickey, who's now struggling to open the bathroom door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing with his hands full) I'll either be unconscious or I won't.  If not, I'll deal with it then.  I'm not gonna worry now about what's gonna be when I'm unconscious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pounding on the door) Mom, come out!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen in the bathroom) Of course there's a God, you idiot! You don't believe in God?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sighing) But if there's a God, then wh-why is there so much evil in the world? (shrugging) What-- Just on a simplistic level. Why-why were there Nazis?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen in the bathroom) Tell him, Max. Mickey, reacting, hits his forehead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) How the hell do I know why there were Nazis?  I don't know how the can opener works. Mickey starts pounding the door again as the movie cuts to: A beautiful snow-covered church downtown, complete with courtyard and wrought-iron fence.  A pedestrian walks by with an umbrella.  A church choir sings a soaring hymn over the scene. The music continues as the film moves inside, where the choir is seen singing behind an altar glowing warm gold.  A fairly large congregation sits in darkened pews as the film cuts to the back, where Mickey, his arms crossed, stands underneath some stained-glass windows, watching and listening to the inspiring music. The choir continues to sing as the movie cuts to Father Flynn in his office. He picks up some large, heavy books from a shelf near his window and he walks over to Mickey, who's standing near his desk, already holding several tomes.  Father Flynn puts the books on top of Mickey's pile; Mickey, flipping through the top one, awkwardly carries his bundle to the door. Next is seen a close-up of a painting of Jesus Christ on the cross, complete with crown of thorns and holy expression. His eyes, especially designed to blink as the lights hit them, open and close repeatedly.  The hymn plays on, loudly, as the camera moves back, revealing Mickey, standing outside a barber shop window, looking at the Christ playing and shuffling from side to side to gets its eyes' 3-D effect. Smaller inspirational pictures border the bigger, blinking Christ.  A barber pole with moving stripes stands nearby; passing traffic is reflected in the window. Mickey turns from the window, shrugging, and starts to walk down the street, past a fruit and vegetable store with open- air-displayed flowers, past several briskly moving pedestrians. With the hymn still playing, the screen goes black briefly. Mickey opens the door, the light from a hallway illuminating him.  He's just entered his apartment.  He closes the door and walks through his dark foyer; he carries a brown bag. He switches on the light, and walking past his spiral staircase, past several framed pictures on the wall, he makes his way to his living room coffee table.  Mickey pulls a crucifix out of the bag; he looks at it, then puts it on the table near a pile of books and some objets d'art.  He then takes out a copy of the New Testament, putting it on top of the crucifix.  Then out comes a framed picture of a saint.  It too gets put on the growing pile.  But the bag is not yet empty.  Next comes a large loaf of Wonder Bread and a large jar of Hellman's mayonnaise.  Mickey sets them on top of the saint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping Hannah's gasp) Hi. The sisters laugh and embrace each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.  Where's Holly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping) Hi.  She's auditioning for a television commercial.  She said she's gonna be a little late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sighing) Oh, yeah?  How's she doing? She turns and walks towards the restaurant entrance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (following Hannah through the restaurant's doors) Oh, God, you know Holly.  When she's depressed, she's manic.  I think it was a good idea that we invited her to lunch. They disappear inside.  The camera follows them, cutting to the restaurant's interior at the same time the sisters walk in.  It's a chic, trendy place, with an Art Deco design and high ceilings.  A waiter in uniform stands near its glass and metal doors, holding a tray to his chest; a few people sit at the bar; a large plant in a vase sits in the foreground.  The sisters walk toward the coatcheck area, deep in conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pulling off her scarf, still on the subject of Holly) I hope you tell her it was your idea...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping) ...'cause every time I try to be helpful, you know, sh-she gets so defensive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (unbuttoning her coat) Oh, Hannah, she's-she's just embarrassed in front of you, that's all. Hannah walks offscreen, farther into the coatcheck room. She talks offscreen as Lee alone is seen, reacting and speaking as well.  In the background, a waiter crosses over to the bar, then walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) So how are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, me, I'm okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Do you miss Frederick?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) I can't believe Elliot and I can't think of someone nice for you to go out with, you know--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting, her voice slightly higher-pitched as she takes off her coat) How are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) I'm okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping) You know, how's everything?  You doing okay?  How's Frederick? (laughing) I mean, Elliot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, overlapping) Y-yeah. Hannah walks out of the coatcheck room without her coat; it's Lee's turn to disappear and check her things.  Now only Hannah can be seen onscreen as the sisters talk.  In the background, the waiter once again walks over to the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (continuing) Oh, he's fine.  He's-he's, I guess he's fine.  I don't know. (shaking her head, her arms crossed) He's been kinda moody lately, the last few months.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen, overlapping) Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  I-I don't know what's wrong with him.  He's just...kind of distant and difficult.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Oh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, gesturing) I've been trying to talk to him about it.  He says everything's fine, but I don't know. Automatically, you know, I leap to the worst conclusions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Like what? As Hannah answers her sister, Holly can be seen entering the restaurant and walking over to the coatcheck area, an unlit cigarette in her mouth, her sunglasses still on her eyes.

You know--something with a future.  I'm not sixteen anymore. (lighting her cigarette) It's just...crazy! (puffing her cigarette) I've got...an idea for a story. More than one.  And I just need a few months, you know, or, uh, a year even. As the camera slowly circles the table, Hannah is seen listening to Holly, her hand on her mouth.

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Well, that-that's good.  It just, uh...it just seems to me that-that six months or a year, if-if you spent it more productively...

direction.raw_text: No.  She, didn't she say it was, um...she said it was in the publicity department.  That-that can lead to other things. The camera is back on Lee.  She looks around tensely, barely listening to the conversation.  She fidgets.  An empty table sits in the background.

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Boy, I knew you'd be discouraging.

direction.raw_text: (overlapping, reacting) You are, Holly.  Stop it.

direction.raw_text: (offscreen) Good.
